items.title: Bump to TFX 0.14.0, Tensorflow 1.14
items.body: TFX 0.14 should be available very soon. When it is, we can bump both TFX and Tensorflow to the new versions. https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/releases

items.title: spotify-tensorflow requires tfx==0.13.0
items.body:
spotify-tensorflow requires `tfx==0.13.0` but it's never actually used.
It's annoying when working with a project that actually uses it on a newer version.

items.body: https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/3197544af38f1ca4d3da68a1f1d98c5030c662df/spotify_tensorflow/tfx/tfdv.py#L129

items.title: TensorFlow compatibility problems
items.body:
Dear developers,

I observed some TensorFlow API usage in your code that might lead to serious compatibility problems(like a crash).

In file `spotify-tensorflow/examples/example_tf_training_tfexample/main.py` you used `tf.concat` and used keyword `axis` to pass the value. However, the parameter `axis` appears in tf v1.0.0. The older parameter is called `concat_dim` in earlier version api. A crash would happen for an earlier version.

I have fixed this issue in #193 
Look forward to your reply! @jkp @mbruggmann @vzctl @dflemstr @protocol7 
Thanks!

items.title: Depend on tfx 0.13 when it's out
items.body: Instead of the individual libs.

items.title: TfDataValidator should be able to infer a schema when schema_path is none
items.body: In `write_stats_and_schema`, if schema is none, we can probably infer the schema from the stats file and upload it.

items.title: [Tfdv] Allow for StatsOptions to be set
items.body:
In [tfDataValidator](https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/master/spotify_tensorflow/tfx/tfdv.py#L36), it should be possible to set an instance of `tensorflow_data_validation.statistics.stats_options.StatsOptions` as an argument to the constructor.
and use it in the call to `generate_statistics_from_tfrecord` like this: https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/master/tensorflow_data_validation/utils/stats_gen_lib.py#L50

items.body:
This tensorflow upgrade removed running the tests against different tensorflow versions but left them in the envlist:

https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/commit/b25fc645b4763e4e9efec44fda7582ddca865498

items.title: py3 support
items.body: Beam 2.11 RC is out - once 2.11 is released with py3 support (and new versions of tft and tfdv are released on top of it), we'll be ready to go here.

items.title: Expose the job_name of TensorflowTask
items.body:
The value of the ML-Engine job name is unpredictable: https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/master/spotify_tensorflow/luigi/tensorflow_task.py#L139-L140
It would be great if this was generated in a protected method (that could be overridden by the user) or caught in a lazy parameter (that the user could access).
I think the first method is the best as it allows the user to use something different than a long uuid which is hard to read.

https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/6765eaf27cf4569c4239441cb08e1416932f7791/tox.ini#L13

cc @daikeshi

items.title: api: on_validate should be called validate_output (to match internal convention)
readme: still referencing `tfdv` extras (which no longer exist)
TFDV luigi example being skipped?
items.body: @brianmartin do you remember why we're skipping this?

items.title: tests/__init__.py: missing license
Clean up requirements.txt
items.body: We should probably clean up requirements.txt and decide which libs go to install_requires and which ones go to extra_requires.

items.title: Clean up tf_schema_utils.py
items.body:
The schema utilities in tf_schema_utils.py are not ideal. We should use `schema_as_feature_spec` in tft to convert a schema to feature_spec, and vice versa. 

`schema_txt_to_feature_spec`: https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/keshi/tft/spotify_tensorflow/tf_schema_utils.py#L239

We probably will need `feature_spec_to_schema_txt` as well

items.title: python tft/tfdv beam job doesn't have job progress status printed to the terminal
items.body: It's a bit annoying that python tft/tfdv beam job doesn't have job progress status printed to the terminal. The only way to check the job status is to log in google dataflow console. We should look into if there's a way to enable printing the job status log while it's running.

items.title: Fix dataset_tests.py and bump tensorflow version to 1.11.0 or higher
tfr-read: Doesn't work without installing extra dependencies
items.body:
A vanilla `pip install spotify-tensorflow` is not currently sufficient to pull in all the dependencies required to run `tfr-read`. It requires `tensorflow` and `tensorflow-transform`.

This is a confusing user experience and we should figure something out here.

items.title: Using `--setup_file` for dependency installation on workers
items.body:
It seems we can use `--setup_file` instead of `--requirements_file`, so we can install tfdv on workers. Currently, tfdv can't be installed via the requirements file and needs to be installed from a wheel package.

https://github.com/tensorflow/model-analysis/blob/master/examples/chicago_taxi/tfdv_analyze_and_validate_dataflow.sh#L64

https://github.com/tensorflow/model-analysis/blob/master/examples/chicago_taxi/setup.py

items.title: Ensure all dependencies have published wheels (i.e. fastavro)
items.body:
For our internal use cases it is common to use the `py27mu` distribution which doesn't have a compatible `fastavro` wheel (which is a dependency of `apache-beam[gcp]`).

Without this, installing `fastavro` on our common base images requires the user to interpret the compilation failure and figure out that `build-essential` is required. This is cognitive overhead and also bulks up the resultant image unnecessarily.

I've submitted a PR upstream to publish `fastavro` wheel for `py27mu`.

See: https://github.com/fastavro/fastavro/pull/306

items.title: ExampleDecoder doesn't encode strings as expected
Reassess whether certain "optional" dependencies should actually be required
items.body:
For example, `xgboost` can very likely stay optional as its relatively niche. Whereas, perhaps `tensorflow-transform` and `tensorflow-data-validation` are packages that make sense in the `requirements.txt`.

cc @andrewsmartin

items.title: Decide on "optional" dependencies location
items.body:
Currently we have a `requirements.txt` and a `test-requirements.txt`. The `test-requirements.txt` includes more than strictly testing concerns: it also has "optional" dependencies. We should rejigger.

cc @andrewsmartin 

------

The `requirements.txt` has the most minimal packages necessary:
https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/d2f093d355a2caa67c1e1566b6b50f4fe4d478f9/requirements.txt#L1-L5

-------

The `test-requirements.txt` has testing utils such as `nose`, while also including "optional" dependencies like `tensorflow-transform`:

https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/d2f093d355a2caa67c1e1566b6b50f4fe4d478f9/test-requirements.txt#L3-L8

vs 

https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/d2f093d355a2caa67c1e1566b6b50f4fe4d478f9/test-requirements.txt#L12-L16

items.title: Tensorflow>=1.11.0 segfaults when running the unit tests
items.body:
I boiled this down to an example which segfaults with vanilla Tensorflow code and filed an issue here: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/23195

This will block any upgrade past 1.10.1.

cc @andrewsmartin @fallonchen

items.title: can we not hard pin to patch version?
items.body:
the requirement.txt specifies:

```
six==1.11.0
pandas==0.22.0
numpy==1.14.0
typing==3.6.4
tensorflow_metadata==0.6.0
```
is there a specific reason of pinning to patch versions, would it fail if we do something like:
```
six>=1.11.0,<2.0.0
pandas>=0.22.0,<1.0.0
numpy>=1.14.0,<2.0.0
typing>=3.6.4,<4.0.0
tensorflow_metadata>=0.6.0,<1.0.0
```
this would allow it to work as long as changes made are backward compatible and then it becomes easier to package this with other libraries and maintaining dependencies.

items.title: TensorFlow is required when installing spotify-tensorflow
items.body:
Right now, there's no tensorflow dependency listed in: https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/master/requirements.txt but if tensorflow is not installed, it fails because of this import https://github.com/spotify/spotify-tensorflow/blob/master/spotify_tensorflow/__init__.py#L22.

I think it is a good idea to not require tensorflow. One use case is using the luigi task definition, to run the tensorflow task with ml-engine. In that case we don't need to have tensorflow installed.

One possible solution is to move that import where it is actually needed.

items.title: Reevaluate if we need/want the Trainer class
items.body:
Trainer API is somewhat a blackbox, might be too high level, most of TF code standardizes on Estimator API, maybe it's fine to stay at Estimator API.

Any opinions @richwhitjr @yonromai ?

items.title: Add utils to promote the use of Keras
items.body: Keras should be easy to use together with sptf lib.

items.title: Remove or Reevaluate the use of TF Flags
items.body:
Currently the library registers TF Flags in a few places.  This leads to few major problems.

1. Flag parser fails on unknown flags which can happen when using another library like jupyter.
2. Initialization order matters.  If new flags are needed they need to be declared prior to import sptf.
3. Also some issues with discoverability of the flags present.
4. __init__ usage currently registers the flags even if they aren't necessary.

items.title: Freeze graph utils should support GCS
items.body: Freeze graph utils should support exporting to GCS.

items.title: Add utility to export saved models
items.body: Add utility - probably somewhere in Trainer to easily export saved model.

items.title: I'm a test issue of an integration!
Make sure we follow `tf.dataset` perf guidelines
items.body: TF has a very nice [doc about `tf.dataset` perf](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/docs_src/performance/datasets_performance.md). We should me sure we follow it.

items.title: Migrate to TF 1.5
items.body:
We should look into migrating to TF 1.5
Here is the [announcement](https://developers.googleblog.com/2018/01/announcing-tensorflow-15.html) and the [release notes](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/releases/tag/v1.5.0).
